clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of Inflight First Aid Performed by Cabin Crew Members and Medical Volunteers

brief_summary.textblock: Since the number of air travelers, including the elderly and passengers with an underlying disease, is increasing every year, the number of inflight emergency patients is expected to increase as well. The investigators attempted to identify the incidence and types of inflight medical emergencies and analyze the first aid performed by cabin crew members or medical volunteers in flights by an Asian airline. The investigators also investigated the causes of inflight deaths and aircraft diversions.

primary_outcome.measure: Types of inflight medical emergencies confirmed by reviewing cabin reports submitted by cabin crew and medical records submitted by medical volunteers
primary_outcome.time_frame: 5 years (events during inflight, excluding events that occured before takeoff or after landing)
primary_outcome.description: Types of inflight medical emergencies were created according to the initial symptoms of passengers (e.g. syncope, trauma)

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of inflight medical emergencies confirmed by reviewing cabin reports submitted by cabin crew and medical records submitted by medical volunteers
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 5 years (events during inflight, excluding events that occured before takeoff or after landing)

secondary_outcome.measure: The causes of inflight deaths and aircraft diversions confirmed by reviewing cabin reports submitted by cabin crew and medical records submitted by medical volunteers
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 5 years (events during inflight, excluding events that occured before takeoff or after landing)
secondary_outcome.description: The causes of deaths and diversions were confirmed by types of inflight

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Inflight medical emergencies from 2009 to 2013
Exclusion Criteria:
- Events that occurred before takeoff or after landing
